ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about the films of the German New Wave from both east and west Germany, more about the historical context of the time, and how to analyze these films using historical context, a filmic lens, and also emotional reaction.

Very flexible course format where you choose what and how much you want to learn about German Cold War Cinema. Everyone is exposed to basic curriculum of films and secondary readings, but other than that you can pick your own topics for the two papers.
I learned a lot about critical analysis and German history as well!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course's structure was pretty sound.
The course has a great professor and thrives on the discussion format! It was slightly overwhelming to have an entire class discussion at times, so breakout rooms would be helpful!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to other students because it exposed me to a lot of amazing films that I wouldnt have otherwise seen.

Yes, as long as that student is disciplined and committed to doing the readings and watching the films. Otherwise they may not get much out of the course, and will be ill-suited to contribute to discussions.
This is a great course if you want to improve your film analysis skills and watch a ton of interesting films from East/West Germany!
